adjectives.description: borderline (comparative more borderline, superlative most borderline)

entries.meaning: Nearly; not clearly on one side or the other of a border or boundary, ambiguous.
examples: I would rather hire a talented layman than a university graduate with borderline qualifications.
Your borderline remarks about my aunt's dress destroyed my evening.

entries.meaning: Nearly; not entirely but nevertheless to a great extent.
examples: He is borderline hypoglycemic and needs to monitor his sugar intake.
I expected him to be super boring but he was actually borderline funny!

entries.meaning: (countable) A boundary or accepted division; a border.
examples: She lives on the borderline between reality and madness.

entries.meaning: (countable) An individual who has borderline personality disorder.
examples: As an example of their affective profile, borderlines are set apart from passive aggressives by having more marked social anxiety  […]  and greater sensitivity  […]

verbs.description: borderline (third-person singular simple present borderlines, present participle borderlining, simple past and past participle borderlined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To border, or border on; to be physically close or conceptually akin to.
